awd_titl_txt: PIRE: DUST stimulated drawn-down of atmospheric CO2 as a trigger for Northern Hemisphere Glaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the geologic processes underlying the long-term global cooling over the past 50 million years (myr) is important for understanding the climate conditions on Earth today. The Northern Hemisphere was largely ice-free 4 myr ago followed by an acceleration of global temperature decline at ~3.6 myr ago, with continental ice sheets developing on northern hemisphere continents by ~2.7 myr ago. Limited atmospheric CO2 records suggest a decline in CO2 from ~400 to ~300 parts per million by volume (ppmv) during that time period could have cooled the Earth sufficiently to enable ice sheets to grow. Yet the cause for this decline in CO2 remains unknown. This international research and educational collaboration between 7 U.S. and 3 Chinese institutions will evaluate a new hypothesis: atmospheric dust derived from Central Asian deserts fertilized the North Pacific ocean, stimulating algal productivity, which in turn drew down atmospheric CO2 leading to Northern Hemisphere Glaciation (NHG). Through field work studies in China, laboratory analyses of ocean and terrestrial sedimentary deposits, and atmospheric and ocean modeling studies, the investigators and students will generate and compare a wide range of paleoclimate records from diverse geological archives to evaluate the role of atmospheric dust in CO2 decline and global cooling at the onset of NHG.  The findings from this research project may ultimately contribute to knowledge with global policy implications.

By evaluating the significance of atmospheric dust in sustaining cool climate conditions on Earth, this study is expected to elucidate the mechanisms of climate cooling in the recent geologic past. Specifically this study will establish records of: 1) the aridification history of Central Asia, northern Tibet, and the Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP) as related to records of deformation and surface uplift in high Asia within and to the west of these regions, 2) wind erosion of Central Asia basins and dust accumulation in the CLP, 3) dust flux, algal productivity, and sea surface temperature in the North Pacific and South Atlantic, and 4) terrestrial CO2 in the interval of 4.5-2.5 Ma. Modeling and sensitivity studies will (1) evaluate the sensitivity of Asian climate and the dust cycle to the growth of topography and to the background global climate; (2) determine the amount of cooling that could result from Pliocene dust transport to the North Pacific; (3) evaluate the potential influence of Asian dust on atmospheric CO2. Through this research program, US graduate students will gain access to research facilities as well as field localities in China that would otherwise be inaccessible and engage in mutually beneficial collaborative research activities with Chinese partners via bilateral visits; US undergraduate students will also have the opportunity to participate in summer schools, workshops, and research projects; the investigators will develop outreach tools for museums to increase public understanding of the role of atmospheric dust in climate change.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project yielded multiple significant scientific findings:

1. Permafrost Evolution: Paleo-temperature studies in northern Tibet reveal a transition from a permafrost-free to a permafrost-covered environment around 2.7 Ma, highlighting alpine region’s role in permafrost-climate feedbacks.

2. Tectonic and Climate Controls: In northern Tibet and Central Asia, tectonics dominated regional climate changes during the middle-late Miocene, while global cooling became the primary driver since the late Pliocene (~3.6 Ma).

3. Central Asian Aridification: Over the past 5 Ma, Asian aridification and dust flux were primarily driven by global climate change rather than tectonic activity.

4. Wind Erosion Impact: Wind erosion reshaped northern China’s topography across spatial scales of 10 meters to over 100 kilometers and timescales from tens of thousands to millions of years.

5. Soil Respiration: Soil respiration rates on the Chinese Loess Plateau declined during the latest Miocene and late Pliocene, likely in response to global cooling.

6. Orbital Forcing on Precipitation: Variations in the magnitude of Earth’s axial tilt caused seasonal shifts in precipitation on the Chinese Loess Plateau.

7. Atmospheric Circulation Shift: During the warmer-than-present Pliocene, westerly winds dominated, but by the Pleistocene, Northern Hemisphere ice sheets exerted stronger control over atmospheric circulation.

8. Ocean and Dust Dynamics: Pliocene and early Pleistocene ocean circulation and dust dynamics differed significantly from present-day conditions.

9. Biological and Iron Cycling: A feedback loop between biological activity and iron cycling suggests that local nutrient availability governs global colimitation of macro- and micronutrients, maximizing biological productivity.

10. Ocean Circulation and Carbon Cycle: Reduced Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC) weakens biological activity, decreasing ligand production, enhancing iron limitation, and leading to incomplete nutrient use and oceanic carbon outgassing, and vice versa.

11. North Pacific Dust and Productivity: A compilation of Pliocene dust and export productivity proxy datasets from across the North Pacific indicates no relationship between North Pacific dust flux and export production in the Pliocene.

12. Threshold of Global Cooling: The intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciation marked a permanent climate shift toward global cooling and ice sheet expansion, driven by declining atmospheric CO₂.

13. Late Miocene Cooling: A synchronous cooling event occurred in both hemispheres between ~7 and 5.4 Ma, bringing ocean temperatures near modern values, likely due to falling atmospheric CO₂ levels.

14. Tectonic Degassing and Climate Evolution: The correlation between mid-ocean ridge spreading rates and global climate evolution suggests that changes in tectonic CO₂ degassing largely controlled long-term ice sheet dynamics and global temperature trends since 20 Ma.

 

Broader Impacts

This project achieved substantial broader impacts:

1. Scientific Contributions: Over 110 peer-reviewed publications resulted from this project, including 18 articles in journals from the Science, Nature, and PNAS publishing groups, as well as 6 review papers.

2. Training and Mentorship: The project supported the training of eight PhD students, four postdoctoral researchers, and numerous undergraduate research assistants at U.S. universities.

3. Conference Support: An international meeting for a broad community of geoscientists extending beyond the project collaborators was organized in Tucson, AZ, in April 2024. The PIRE project provided travel, accommodation, and meal support for twenty-one students and early-career researchers, including fifteen participants from U.S. institutions, three from South America, two from Asia, and one from Africa.

4. Education Outreach: The project’s outreach team developed innovative educational materials, including interactive museum activities and Science on a Sphere visualizations. Activity kits were presented at national conferences and distributed to 14 museums across the U.S.

5. Online Resources: A dedicated website, Exploring Atmospheric Dust and Climate (https://scied.ucar.edu/atmospheric-dust-climate), was created to host educational materials and outreach resources.

6. Global Accessibility: Educational activity materials were translated into Mandarin Chinese, expanding access to broader international audiences.
